node.title: How the Ukraine crisis affects China's view on Taiwan
node.description: Host Michael Morell talks with senior CSIS fellow Chris Johnson about how China would like the Ukraine conflict to end.

node.title: Court quashes teens' legal bid for protection against climate change
node.description: An Australian appeals court overturned a ruling that said the environment minister had a duty to protect young people from the impact of global warming.

node.title: Ukraine's president to push for more help in address to U.S. Congress
node.description: Volodymyr Zelenskyy's appeal will come as Russia keeps pounding infrastructure in the capital of Kyivand many other cities with artillery strikes.

node.title: Vintage shunt goes west as KiwiRail switches to electric option
node.description: KiwiRail's oldest diesel shunt is rolling full steam ahead into retirement.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 24 more deaths in NZ, 19,542 new cases
node.description: There have been 19,542 new cases of Covid-19 in the community and 24 more deaths reported today.

node.title: Vehicles, assets worth over $1m seized in Hawke's Bay
node.description: Police say they have executed search warrants to take back property they allege belongs to a man facing significant drugs charges.

node.title: Global dairy prices fall for first time this year
node.description: It was the first decline in prices since late December, and followed a series of auctions which averaged 4.5 percent gains.

node.title: Elderly women robbed after win on gambling machines
node.description: A 32-year-old Hastings man has been arrested after two elderly women who had won money on gambling machines were followed, attacked and robbed on Monday afternoon.

node.title: Parliament grounds reopened: 'It is about restoring the mana'
node.description: Wellington mana whenua say a ceremony this morning reopening the walkways at Parliament grounds is about healing after the occupation and riot there earlier this month.

node.title: New initiative to help support rural practices and hospitals
node.description: It will help fill short-term staffing gaps in rural practices and hospitals due to Covid-19 illness and isolation requirements.

node.title: More uptake of central city offices in Christchurch and Wellington
node.description: Research from commercial real estate firm CBRE says it partially reflects strong economic growth following lockdowns last year.

node.title: Drive-through vaccinations an option as Māori bear Omicron brunt
node.description: A Māori health provider will offer Taranaki's first drive-through Covid-19 vaccinations in the region's towns this weekend.

node.title: Increased police presence in Kaikohe after gang violence
node.description: Northland police have arrested a number of gang members after what they describe as a vicious and cowardly assault on a man in daylight on Kaikohe's main street.

node.title: Pharmac funds new lung cancer, asthma medicines
node.description: Pharmac has secured an agreement for medicines for treating people with lung cancer, ovarian cancer or severe asthma.

node.title: Geoffrey Miller: Ukraine puts NZ refugee policy, China strategy under scrutiny
node.description: International analyst Geoffrey Miller puts New Zealand's new humanitarian visa policy for Ukrainians under the microscope and considers the implications of claims of a potential role for China in…

node.title: 'Difficult and dangerous moment': Kyiv's mayor announces curfew
node.description: Russian air strikes and shelling smashed into buildings in the Ukrainian capital Kyiv as invading forces tightened their grip, and three European prime ministers were due to arrive in the city.

node.title: Protesters disperse after months of occupation at Raglan Airfield
node.description: A group of protesters that had been gathered at the Raglan Airfield since January have left today.

node.title: West Coasters explore new business opportunities during pandemic
node.description: Financial uncertainty has not deterred some West Coast business owners who have taken the plunge and set up shop in the midst of the pandemic.

node.title: More work needed on hate speech as Parliament marks mosque attacks
node.description: A motion in Parliament to mark the Christchurch mosque terror attacks anniversary found MPs reflecting on how there is still work to do to counter extremism and hate speech. Audio

node.title: Nicola Willis revealed as National's new finance spokesperson
node.description: Nicola Willis will take over the Finance portfolio left vacant by Simon Bridges, while Chris Bishop will take over her Housing role.

node.title: Customs seize 700 kilograms of cocaine in shipping container from South America
node.description: Customs have seized more than 700 kilograms of cocaine in a shipping container, breaking the record for a border seizure that was set just two weeks ago.

node.title: North Korea attempted launch fails, South Korea says
node.description: It wasn't immediately clear what North Korea launched on Wednesday morning or at what stage it had an apparent failure.

node.title: Tokyo Olympian Rebecca Petch wins on both track and BMX
node.description: Tokyo Olympian Rebecca Petch has shown her impressive cycling diversity in winning two national titles in just three days.

node.title: Kremlin says West's sanctions affect Iranian nuclear deal
node.description: The Kremlin has cautioned the West that Russia's interests as part of the Iranian nuclear deal would have to be ensured.

node.title: Chip crunch forces further production cuts at Toyota
node.description: Toyota says it will make additional production cuts in March due to a shortage of semiconductor chips.

node.title: Chris Hipkins tests positive for Covid-19
node.description: The minister in charge of New Zealand's Covid-19 response has now himself tested positive for the coronavirus.

node.title: Country Life: Ripe for the picking
node.description: Fourth generation grower Kevin Jackson and his team go out on a limb to ensure the harvesting season runs smoothly at Jackson Orchards in Cromwell. Audio

node.title: Schools to receive rapid antigen tests from government
node.description: Schools, kura and early learning centres will soon be able to opt-in to receive rapid antigen tests, the government has announced.

node.title: Medics and volunteers try to prop up Ukraine's health system
node.description: When Russian bombs started falling on Kyiv, oncologist Nataliia Verovkina fled with her 10-year-old son.

node.title: How Covid-19 restrictions might change after NZ's Omicron peak
node.description: The government today outlines its plan for a fast-tracked border reopening, and will soon decide what happens to vaccine passes and mandates after the Omicron peak.
